documentType: Bureau of Prisons medical/psychological assessment records
summary: This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological and medical records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, including suicide risk assessments, intake screenings, risk of sexual abusiveness evaluations, and lab results. The records show Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation after a court appearance, was assessed as low suicide risk, and refused an eye doctor evaluation. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, including his refusal of medical treatments and a clinical encounter following an apparent suicide attempt. It also includes internal BOP and DOJ emails discussing staffing issues, suicide prevention protocols, and a planned visit by the U.S. Attorney's office to the MCC following Epstein's death. This document is a series of email exchanges from August 12, 2019, discussing staffing issues and media response at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes internal discussions about countering CNN's reporting on staff shortages and provides detailed staffing statistics and absence data for the facility.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of all assessments; a 66-year-old inmate at MCC New York facing federal sex trafficking charges, assessed for suicide risk and sexual abusiveness risk.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: Conducted the suicide risk assessment on July 9, 2019, and consulted with Central Office regarding Epstein's risk factors.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: Conducted the intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted], Central Office
persons.role: Bureau of Prisons Central Office Psychologist
persons.context: Consulted with the on-site chief psychologist regarding Epstein's suicide risk factors on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, with whom he does not have a relationship.

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein; he expressed confidence in his attorney, described as competent, and wanted to meet with him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the medical records; documented refusing medical treatment and being treated for injuries after being found with a rope around his neck in his cell.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York; listed as a visitor for a tour of the MCC, specifically requesting to see Epstein's cell and suicide watch areas.

persons.name: Elissa Miller
persons.context: Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center; corresponded via email regarding an inquiry about inmate Epstein's mental capability for disciplinary process.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: Medical provider who conducted the clinical encounter with Epstein on July 23, 2019, after he was found injured.

persons.name: Kugler
persons.context: BOP official mentioned in an email chain discussing an Inmate Suicide Prevention Program memo following Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: K Griffith
persons.context: Email participant discussing how to respond to CNN's reporting on MCC staffing issues and whether to provide talking points to the DOJ.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: MCC staff member whose overtime schedule is detailed; worked a regular shift on 11/9 and overtime from 1am to an unspecified time.

persons.name: Thomas
persons.context: MCC employee whose overtime work on specific dates (7/30, 8/6, 8/1, 8/7) is listed as part of staffing analysis.

connections.description: Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney and requested to meet with him.
Epstein identified his brother as his only family but stated they do not have a relationship.
The on-site psychologist consulted with the Central Office psychologist regarding Epstein's suicide risk.
MLP provided medical assessment and treatment to Epstein following his injury in custody.
MD provided chronic care medical evaluations and treatment for Epstein's various health conditions.
As U.S. Attorney, Berman planned a visit to the MCC to inspect the location of Epstein's death and related areas as part of the investigation.
As Chief Psychologist, Miller was involved in an inquiry regarding Epstein's mental capability for disciplinary proceedings.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding which potentially gave him bad news regarding his legal situation, leading to precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Intake and Risk Assessments
events.description: Epstein underwent Bureau of Prisons intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment upon arrival at MCC New York.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A chief psychologist conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein, finding low acute risk and absent chronic risk.

events.title: Epstein Refuses Eye Doctor Evaluation
events.description: Epstein signed a form refusing recommended treatment for an eye doctor evaluation.

events.title: Epstein refuses chest X-ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signed a form refusing a recommended routine chest X-ray at the MCC.

events.title: Epstein chronic care evaluation
events.description: A physician conducted a chronic care evaluation of Epstein, noting his medical history including hypertriglyceridemia, sleep apnea, and back pain.

events.title: Epstein found injured in cell
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell in the Special Housing Unit with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He was assessed by medical staff, placed on suicide watch, and had marks on his neck.

events.title: Inquiry on Epstein's mental capability
events.description: An email inquiry was sent to Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller asking whether inmate Epstein was mentally capable of proceeding with the disciplinary process.

events.title: U.S. Attorney's office plans MCC visit
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's office, led by Geoffrey Berman, planned a visit to the MCC to tour the suicide watch area, SHU, and Epstein's cordoned-off cell.

events.title: Discussion of suicide prevention memo
events.description: Following Epstein's suicide, BOP officials discussed a memo regarding inmate suicide prevention, noting that wardens were leaving inmates on suicide watch longer than psychologists advised.

events.title: Internal Email Discussion on MCC Staffing and Media Response
events.description: Internal government/BOP email chain discussing CNN's reporting on staffing shortages at MCC New York following Epstein's death, and coordinating potential talking points for the DOJ to counter the narrative.

events.title: MCC New York Career Fair
events.description: MCC New York held a career fair at 290 Broadway with 174 potential applicants in attendance, as part of recruitment efforts.

events.title: MCC Correctional Services Staff Absence Period
events.description: Detailed accounting of Correctional Services staff absences (Sick Leave, LWOP, AWOL, etc.) at MCC New York over an 8-day period, showing significant unfilled posts.

locations: MCC New York (NYM) - Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York
1900 W. Sunshine Street, Springfield, MO 65807 - U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisons
New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007
Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124 (Epstein's cell location)
Health Services Unit H01 (Medical unit at MCC)
keyFacts: On July 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed as having a low acute suicide risk and absent chronic suicide risk, despite having risk factors like a high-profile case and recent court proceeding.
Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation on July 8, 2019, due to risk factors including sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and potential bad news from court.
A risk of sexual abusiveness assessment on July 8, 2019, found Epstein at low risk of abusiveness in the facility, noting his history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
Epstein refused an eye doctor evaluation on July 24, 2019, signing a medical treatment refusal form.
Lab results from July 9-10, 2019, showed Epstein had high cholesterol (216 mg/dL), high triglycerides (413 mg/dL), and a Hemoglobin A1C of 6.3% (indicating diabetes).
Jeffrey Epstein refused recommended medical treatments, including an eye doctor evaluation and a routine chest X-ray, in July 2019.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck and marks on his neck; he was placed on suicide watch and assessed by medical staff.
Internal BOP emails reveal staffing challenges and discussions about suicide prevention protocols following Epstein's death.
U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman planned a visit to the MCC to inspect Epstein's cell and suicide watch areas in August 2019.
An email inquiry was made regarding Epstein's mental capability for disciplinary proceedings on July 24, 2019, the day after his injury.
CNN reported that one of the officers on Epstein's unit was not a 'full fledged' correctional officer, which prompted internal government discussion.
Internal emails show DOJ/BOP personnel coordinating talking points to counter CNN's narrative about staffing shortages at MCC New York.
MCC New York had significant staffing challenges: 84.86% overall staffing, 83.70% Correctional Services staffing, 19 vacant officer positions, and 41 positions in various recruitment stages.
Detailed absence data for Correctional Services from 8/3/19 to 8/10/19 shows 177 posts unfilled over 8 days due to various leave types.
The facility had implemented recruitment incentives (10% relocation and recruitment incentives) and advertising campaigns to address staffing shortages.
